headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Amherst: Anti-Obesity Coverage Suggested

docs.abstract: Sarah Ferguson, Duchess of York, tells group of 700 Weight Watchers enthusiasts in Amherst, NY, that membership in anti-obesity groups should be covered by Medicare or Medicaid; says Britain's health care system is considering such a proposal; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: On an eight-city tour for Weight Watchers, for which she is a spokeswoman, Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York, said yesterday that membership to such anti-obesity groups should be covered by Medicare or Medicaid. Great Britain's health care system is considering such a proposal, she told 700 Weight Watcher enthusiasts at a meeting in Amherst, a Buffalo suburb. ''Yes, I can travel around inspiring people,'' said Ms. Ferguson, who has lobbied on Capitol Hill on weight-related health issues. ''But let's get the country to be a bit more supportive and realizing it's a killer.''
docs.snippet: On an eight-city tour for Weight Watchers, for which she is a spokeswoman, Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York, said yesterday that membership to such anti-obesity groups should be covered by Medicare or Medicaid. Great Britain's health care system...

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses food products that claim to be good for consumers; Dr Marion Nestle, former head of nutrition and now professor of public health at New York University, holds that food companies use claims to distract public from noticing caloric content under guise that any quantity of consumption is acceptable since product is healthy; low carbohydrate trend discussed; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: You may think that a genuine interest in consumer health prompts food companies to market products that claim to reduce the risk of heart disease or cancer or help people lose weight. Think again. Many food companies are interested in one thing -- the most efficient route to extra sales. The more products consumers buy and the more of them they eat, the fatter the companies' coffers. And, alas, the fatter the consumers are likely to be, as well.
docs.snippet: You may think that a genuine interest in consumer health prompts food companies to market supposedly healthful products. Think again.

docs.lead_paragraph: WORKPLACE stress is back in the news. American workers are frazzled to the point of illness, experts say, and enlightened employers are offering yoga classes, massage and other palliatives to combat the problem. Talk about civilization and its discontents. If you find the modern, air-conditioned workplace stressful -- all that e-mail! -- just think back to the work most Americans used to do. Men were farmhands, coal miners, steelworkers and the like, working every day with the risk of death or destitution hovering nearby. Women who worked outside the home were poorly paid for difficult jobs -- often as domestics or millworkers, toiling at the whim of wealthy employers. Opportunities for minorities were extremely limited, and discrimination against blacks, for example, was so acute that most were excluded from all but the most menial jobs. Now that's stress.
docs.snippet: Though workplace stress is back in the news, the problems that U.S. workers face today don't compare with those faced by earlier generations.

headline.main: Coke Says 2nd-Half Profit Will Fall Short

docs.abstract: Coca-Cola Co warns investors that problems in North America and Europe will cause its profits for second half to fall short of expectations; its stock to fall to its lowest level this year; chief executive E Neville Isdell faces many challenges to reviving company; graph; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The Coca-Cola Company warned yesterday that its earnings for the second half of the year would fall short of forecasts, citing competitive pressures in North America and unseasonably cool and rainy weather in Europe. The warning is the first setback for Coke's chief executive, E. Neville Isdell, who came out of retirement in June to assume the top post.
docs.snippet: Coca-Cola warned that its earnings will fall short of forecasts, pointing to competition in North America and poor weather in Europe.
